awd_titl_txt: NRI: FND: Hybrid Active-Passive Actuation for Safety and Performance in Physical Human-Robot Collaboration and Rehabilitation
awd_abstract_narration:
Physical cooperation between a person and a robot requires a range of performance characteristics that is difficult for traditional robots to meet. Sometimes a robot must have high stiffness to support an object for a person to work with or to perform a precise task of its own, but at other times it must have low stiffness to ensure the safety of a person who makes contact with it. Sometimes a robot must control the interaction force between itself and a person, but at other times it must move along a precise path regardless of the force applied to it. Existing actuators such as electric, pneumatic or hydraulic motors cannot achieve this performance combination, so a new approach to robotic actuators is required. This National Robotics Initiative (NRI) research project will study the design and control of robots that use a combination of active components (motors) and passive components (brakes) to meet these opposing demands. This actuation approach, referred to as Balanced Active-Passive Hybrid Actuation, will provide high power capabilities while possessing the unique characteristics required for human-robot physical collaboration. This research will enable new capabilities for cooperation between people and robots and will open unserved application areas such as cooperative high-power manufacturing robots, high-power rehabilitation robots, and high-performance exoskeletons. One important application is rehabilitation robotics for retraining intentional movement after neural injury such as stroke. The hybrid active-passive actuators developed in this research will be applied to create a strong and accurate, yet also safe, rehabilitation robot for the legs, which will be used to test leg force and movement control and develop rehabilitation methods for stroke survivors. 

The goal of this project is to develop design principles and control approaches for hybrid active-passive actuators capable of providing high power and high force-control bandwidth. The research will combine a series-elastic electric motor for low-bandwidth force control, a parallel direct-drive electric motor for high-bandwidth force control, and a parallel brake for efficient very high-bandwidth support against applied external forces. A physical test actuator will be built according to these design principles and used to develop and test a bandwidth-partitioning controller for coordinating the multiple actuators. The resulting design and control techniques will be used to build a two-axis parallel linkage manipulator for applying arbitrary planar force fields to the foot of a human user. The system will be tested for its ability to haptically render virtual mechanical environments such as viscous curl fields. These curl fields will be used to study motor control of the leg, with the goal of developing rehabilitative tasks for stroke survivors to promote the recovery of coordinated movement and postural control.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit:

This project aimed to develop a new kind of actuator, suitable for human-interactive robots, and build it into a robotic platform suitable for use in studies of human movement control and rehabilitation in the legs. The actuator is a hybrid of three other common types of actuator: a large, slow electric motor with a spring in series, called a series-elastic actuator, to support large forces; a small, fast electric motor that acts directly to compensate for the slow response of the series-elastic actuator; and a particle brake, which can be controlled electronically to absorb, but not supply, energy. The project studied the design and control of this new hybrid actuator in depth, including developing detailed models of each component and a control scheme that partitions the desired output torque among the three based on the current state of the whole system. These models generated a real-time, responsive, control system as well as a model-predictive control system for intentional trajectory movements. Results included improving the ability to stiffly hold a position when perturbed by outside forces (termed the virtual wall stiffness), and the ability of the system to coordinate all three actuators together to make pre-planned trajectory movements more quickly than any of the components could do on their own.

In parallel, the project developed approaches for studying human motor control in the legs using haptic robots (i.e., robots that use controlled interaction forces). An existing one-degree-of-freedom robot was used to probe test participants’ ability to learn to move with novel kinds of forces applied to their legs. Tests included spring-like forces, damper-like forces, and other relationships between movement and force that have not been experienced before. Findings characterized how quickly people can adapt to or learn these perturbed movement tasks, and the importance of individual preferences in how that learning and adaptation is performed.

Finally, two of the new actuators were produced and assembled into a two-degree-of-freedom robot with a linkage suitable for interacting with the human leg. The combined system was programmed to create novel two-dimensional relationships between motion and force. These include virtual walls and a viscous curl field. The development of control for this system uncovered special considerations that need to be accounted for in coordinating the two actuators, which did not appear in each actuator alone. This robot will ultimately be used to test more complex movements in the legs and to develop protocols that promote rehabilitation of impaired movement control after injuries such as stroke.

Broader Impact:

This project has created new knowledge of how to control haptic robots, and has generated demonstration equipment that has helped visitors understand how robots can be used for human interaction more safely and with greater information content than typical robots convey. Long-term impacts will include new ways to assess and rehabilitate deficits in motor control of the legs, and thus have impacts on human health and well-being.
